annotation.TEXT: This is one of the sections I don't really care for. The rising and falling flames are a decent hazard, but they can quickly become irksome when they start piling up on-screen. The flying enemies here also don't really help matters either. It's a doable section, but it can certainly be annoying as well.

For this particular level, there's nothing to really write home about. There's no central gimmick to this stage (unless you count the needles from MM3). Though by comparing it to the earlier entries, this one's layout and enemy placement shows a better understanding of what usually makes a Mega Man stage fun.

With Tier 4 done, the only thing left are the top levels in Tier 5 (and the inevitable Wily Fortress). Since I have a bit of time left though, I figured I'd walk around and talk to some of the Robot Masters. As I said before, their advice isn't really anything too groundbreaking. A bit of dialogue from one of them will become important later, however.

Justice Man is simple enough to deal with, but some of his attacks can be a pain if you're going into this fight blind. His homing shots in particular can become unavoidable without using Rush Coil (depending on how you move when he does this attack). Some of his moves like the Charge Shot and Slide also have no telegraphs behind them, which basically leaves you to guess when he'll use them.

This wouldn't be so bad if the blocks were limited in their usage. Instead, there's an entire bridge section made of them. The refill problem is especially noticeable here, seeing as there's several enemies littering the area (which will immediately send you into the pit if you get hit by any of them). Essentially, this section is a blemish on an otherwise decent level.

Someone can feel free to correct me if I'm wrong, but I'm pretty certain this stage has the first instance of custom enemies. Mainly, it comes in the form of mini-bosses. I won't spoil what they are, but you can probably take a pretty good guess on them if you haven't seen them before.
Beyond having some unique tile-sets, this stage also has a pretty good layout. This would actually be one of my favorite stages in the game, if not for two particular sections...

Much like the original Wily Archive, these ones share a health-bar and all have their own weaknesses. With that being said, they're still easy to take on with the buster. The only one that warrants weapon usage is the final one (and it's mainly due to sharing some problems with the original source boss, so to speak).

The last archive machine imitates a Wily Capsule. Unfortunately, it has the exact same problem as nearly every other Wily Capsule: Its attacks aren't telegraphed in the slightest (with the exception of the homing orbs, which actually do have some start-up time). Its other two attacks come out almost instantly. What also doesn't help is that you can only get a single hit on this thing every time it appears (so if you do plan on fighting it with just the buster, prepare to get frustrated if it appears out of your range a few times in a row).

The other thing I don't like about this level is the falling blocks, but this is more-so due to programming oversights. Essentially, if you pick up an item while walking across these blocks (be it health or weapon refilling ones), you'll immediately fall with whatever block you were standing on once the game un-pauses after the refill (which is also another reason not to buy the Energy Balancer). Sliding can't save you from this either, but jumping seems to work (most of the time, at least).

After everything that's happened with the last three sections, I'm pleased to say that Tier 4 is a pretty large step up in terms of quality. From this point on, the levels will start having more interesting layouts and gimmicks, on top of just generally being more fun to play through.

Not much to really say about this stage either, though one thing I should note on is the music. It's actually an 8-bit arrangement of a song from "Megaman X: Variable Zero," another in-progress fan-game that I don't think I've mentioned yet (until now, anyways).
